A swarm of normal-sized bats does not pose a direct threat in terms of causing physical harm, but their erratic flight patterns can confuse individuals within their vicinity. For every ten bats present in the area, one creature may become disoriented; affected creatures suffer a penalty of -2 on all attack and saving throw rolls while the bats remain nearby.

monsters.name: Giant Bat
monsters.description:
Bats possess a natural sonar that enables them to navigate and perceive their surroundings even in total darkness; for gaming purposes, consider this ability equivalent to Darkvision.

Giant bats boast an impressive wingspan of 15 feet and weigh approximately 200 pounds. They possess the same sensory capabilities as their smaller counterparts but, due to their larger size, they are capable of launching attacks on adventurers. Many giant bats are carnivorous, increasing the likelihood of hostile encounters.

monsters.name: Black Bear
monsters.description:
Black bears, renowned for their versatility as omnivores, have a varied diet that includes nuts, berries, insects, small mammals, and occasionally carrion. Their adaptability allows them to thrive in diverse habitats, ranging from dense forests to mountainous regions and even suburban areas. Despite their formidable size and strength, black bears are generally solitary and elusive, preferring to avoid confrontations with humans.

However, when a female black bear senses a threat to her cubs, her maternal instinct kicks in, and she becomes exceptionally defensive. In such situations, she will not hesitate to confront potential threats, displaying aggressive behavior to protect her offspring. This defensive behavior can manifest in vocalizations, such as huffing or growling, as well as physical displays like charging or swiping with her claws.

It's important to note that black bears typically prefer to avoid conflicts with humans and will often retreat if given the opportunity. Understanding their behavior and respecting their space is key to minimizing encounters and ensuring the safety of both humans and bears in shared habitats.

monsters.name: Cave Bear
monsters.description:
Towering over their brown bear counterparts, cave bears are behemoths of the wilderness, with some individuals reaching astonishing weights of up to 1,800 pounds. Standing on all fours, they loom as high as six feet at the shoulder, casting an imposing presence in their domain. Unlike their more docile relatives, cave bears are ferocious predators, renowned for their relentless aggression towards any creature deemed prey.

Their massive size and muscular build afford cave bears a formidable advantage in the wild. Armed with powerful claws and jaws capable of crushing bone, they are fearsome hunters capable of taking down prey much larger than themselves. From deer to smaller predators and even unwary humans, few creatures are safe from the wrath of a hungry cave bear.

Despite their intimidating appearance and predatory instincts, cave bears are not mindless killers. Like all apex predators, they possess a keen intelligence honed by years of survival in their harsh environments. They are cunning hunters, employing stealth and ambush tactics to secure their next meal.

Encounters with cave bears are a harrowing experience for any traveler brave or foolish enough to venture into their territory. Their roars echo through the caverns they call home, striking fear into the hearts of those who dare to cross their path. Surviving an encounter with a cave bear requires quick thinking, resourcefulness, and a healthy dose of luck, for few adversaries can match the sheer power and ferocity of these monstrous beasts

monsters.name: Grizzly Bear
monsters.description:
Brown bears, also known as grizzly bears in certain regions, are imposing creatures of the wild renowned for their formidable size, carnivorous diet, and aggressive demeanor. Adult males typically weigh between 400 to 800 pounds, standing an impressive four feet tall at the shoulder. Females, while slightly smaller in stature, are no less formidable and share the same bloodthirsty nature as their male counterparts.

These apex predators command respect in their ecosystems, possessing immense strength and powerful jaws lined with sharp teeth and claws. With their keen sense of smell and acute hearing, brown bears are skilled hunters capable of taking down prey as large as moose or bison. Despite their omnivorous diet, which includes vegetation such as berries and roots, meat forms a significant portion of their sustenance, particularly during the salmon runs in regions like Alaska and the Pacific Northwest.

While brown bears are often portrayed as solitary creatures, they are not averse to defending their territories or asserting dominance over rivals. During the mating season or when confronted with threats to their food sources or offspring, these bears can become highly aggressive, displaying intimidating behaviors such as charging, growling, and even standing on their hind legs to appear more imposing.

Encounters with brown bears in the wild demand caution and respect, as provoking or startling these powerful animals can have deadly consequences. Understanding their behaviors and adhering to proper safety protocols, such as storing food securely and making noise while hiking in bear country, are essential for minimizing conflicts and ensuring the safety of both humans and bears alike.

monsters.name: Polar Bear
monsters.description:
Polar bears, native to the icy realms of the far northern regions, stand as majestic yet formidable predators of the Arctic. Towering over their brown bear counterparts, they are larger and possess a robust build, making them one of the largest bear species on Earth. With their sleek white fur camouflaging them against the snow and ice, polar bears blend seamlessly into their frigid surroundings as they prowl the frozen landscapes in search of prey.

These apex predators are renowned for their raw power and predatory prowess. With males weighing up to 1,500 pounds and standing over ten feet tall when on their hind legs, and females not far behind, polar bears command respect in their harsh environment. Despite their seemingly docile appearance while resting on the ice, polar bears are just as hostile and aggressive as their brown bear relatives, particularly when hungry or protecting their young.

With their acute sense of smell and keen hunting instincts, polar bears primarily prey on seals, which they hunt by stalking them at breathing holes or ambushing them near seal pupping grounds. However, as opportunistic feeders, they will scavenge on carcasses, hunt smaller mammals, and even feed on vegetation when necessary.

Encounters with polar bears are rare but potentially dangerous for humans venturing into their habitat. As top predators with no natural enemies, polar bears may perceive humans as potential prey or threats, leading to confrontations. Understanding polar bear behavior and taking appropriate precautions, such as traveling in groups, carrying bear deterrents, and maintaining a safe distance, are crucial for ensuring safety in polar bear territory.

monsters.name: Antelope
monsters.description:
Antelopes are agile and swift herbivores found primarily in the grasslands, savannas, and semi-arid regions of Africa, Asia, and parts of North America. They are characterized by their slender build, long legs, and distinctive horns, which vary in shape and size among different species. Antelopes exhibit remarkable adaptability to their environments, ranging from the iconic herds of the African plains to the rugged mountainous terrain of their habitats.

These herbivores play a vital role in their ecosystems as grazers, feeding on a variety of grasses, herbs, and shrubs. Their feeding habits help maintain the balance of plant populations and contribute to the overall health of their habitats. Antelopes have evolved sophisticated social structures and communication systems to navigate their environments and coordinate group behaviors, such as migration and predator evasion.

During the breeding season, male antelopes often engage in fierce competitions for mating rights, displaying impressive prowess and stamina in battles with rival males. These contests may involve clashes of horns, vocalizations, and elaborate displays of dominance. Female antelopes give birth to single offspring after a gestation period of several months, typically seeking out concealed locations to protect their vulnerable young from predators.

monsters.name: Auroch
monsters.description: The Auroch, an imposing and majestic bovine species, once roamed the expansive landscapes of Europe, Asia, and North Africa. Renowned for their colossal size and formidable presence, Aurochs stood at towering heights of 6 to 7 feet at the shoulder, with muscular frames adorned by formidable, curved horns spanning several feet in length. Their dark, coarse fur served as protection against the elements, accentuating their dominance in the untamed wilderness. Aurochs held a central role in the ancient cultures and mythologies of civilizations, revered for their raw power, resilience, and primal essence. However, with the encroachment of human civilization and hunting pressures, the Auroch eventually met its demise, leaving behind a legacy of awe and reverence in the annals of folklore and mythology.

monsters.name: Deer
monsters.description:
Deer are graceful and elegant herbivores found in various habitats across the world. They are known for their slender bodies, long legs, and branching antlers (in males of most species). Adult deer typically stand around 3 to 5 feet tall at the shoulder, with males generally larger and more robust than females. Their coat coloration varies depending on the species and the environment they inhabit, ranging from reddish-brown to gray or even white in some cases.

Deer are primarily crepuscular, meaning they are most active during dawn and dusk, although they may be spotted foraging at other times of the day. They have keen senses, particularly their hearing and sense of smell, which they rely on to detect predators and other threats. When startled or threatened, deer can swiftly flee with remarkable speed and agility, bounding gracefully through their woodland habitats.

During mating season, known as the rut, males engage in impressive displays of dominance and aggression to compete for mating rights with females. This often involves vocalizations, posturing, and clashes between rival males using their antlers. Female deer, known as does, give birth to one or two fawns after a gestation period of around six to seven months. Fawns are born with white spots on their reddish-brown coat, providing them with camouflage in their forest surroundings.

Deer are primarily browsers, feeding on a variety of vegetation including grasses, leaves, shoots, and twigs. They play a crucial role in shaping the ecosystems they inhabit through their feeding habits and interactions with plant communities.

In folklore and mythology, deer are often associated with qualities such as grace, gentleness, and swiftness, and they hold symbolic significance in many cultures around the world.

monsters.name: Elk
monsters.description:
Elk, also known as wapiti, are majestic herbivores found in various habitats across North America, Europe, and Asia. They are notable for their large size, with adult males, known as bulls, standing around 5 to 5.5 feet tall at the shoulder and weighing up to 700 pounds or more. Females, called cows, are slightly smaller and lack the impressive antlers of the males. Elk are distinguishable by their reddish-brown coats, which darken in color during the winter months, and their broad, branching antlers, which can span up to 4 feet in width. These antlers are shed and regrown annually, with the size and intricacy of the antlers serving as a display of dominance and breeding fitness among males.

Elk are primarily crepuscular, like deer, and are most active during dawn and dusk. They inhabit a range of ecosystems, including forests, grasslands, and alpine meadows, where they feed on a diverse diet of grasses, shrubs, and tree bark. Their keen senses of smell and hearing aid in detecting predators, while their swift running speeds and powerful hooves provide defense against threats.

During the rutting season in the fall, male elk engage in fierce battles for dominance and mating rights. These contests involve vocalizations, posturing, and clashes of antlers, with the victor earning the privilege to mate with receptive females. Female elk give birth to a single calf in the spring, which they protect fiercely from predators.

Elk hold significant cultural and ecological importance in the regions they inhabit, featuring prominently in Native American folklore and playing key roles in maintaining the balance of ecosystems through their grazing habits and interactions with other wildlife species.

monsters.name: Moose
monsters.description:
Moose, the largest member of the deer family, are iconic herbivores found in the northern regions of North America, Europe, and Asia. These majestic creatures are renowned for their towering stature, with adult males, known as bulls, standing up to 6 to 7 feet tall at the shoulder and weighing as much as 1,500 pounds or more. Females, called cows, are slightly smaller in size but still impressive compared to other deer species. Moose are characterized by their dark brown coats, long legs, and broad, palmate antlers, which can span up to 6 feet in width. Their antlers are shed and regrown annually, with the largest individuals sporting impressive racks that serve as a display of dominance and breeding prowess.

Moose are primarily solitary animals, though they may form loose aggregations during the breeding season or in areas with abundant food resources. They inhabit a variety of ecosystems, including boreal forests, marshlands, and tundra, where they feed on a diverse diet of aquatic vegetation, twigs, leaves, and grasses. Their large, bulbous noses and specialized lips allow them to forage underwater for aquatic plants, making them well-adapted to their watery habitats.

Despite their massive size, moose are surprisingly agile and can navigate through dense vegetation and snow with ease. They have keen senses of smell and hearing, which they use to detect predators such as wolves and bears. When threatened, moose can be formidable adversaries, using their powerful hooves and sharp antlers to defend themselves and their young.

In Native American folklore and mythology, moose often feature as symbols of strength, resilience, and endurance, revered for their majestic presence in the wilderness. They play an important ecological role in their ecosystems, shaping vegetation communities through their browsing habits and providing a vital food source for predators.

monsters.name: Carnivorous Ape
monsters.description: Carnivorous apes resemble ordinary gorillas, but they are known for their bad-tempered and aggressive behavior. Despite being omnivores, they exhibit a strong preference for meat. Adult females typically stand between 4Â½ to 5 feet tall and weigh up to 300 pounds, while males are larger, reaching heights of 5Â½ to 6 feet and weighing up to 400 pounds.

Goblins are small, reputedly wicked humanoids. They are cunning and vicious, and very sneaky. Adult goblins are 3 to 3Â½ feet tall and weigh 40 to 45 pounds, with very little difference between males and females. Their skin color ranges from gray to green, and their eyes are usually bright and crafty-looking, varying in color from red to yellow.

All goblins have Darkvision with a range of 30 feet. The statistics given above are for a standard Goblin in leather armor with a shield; they have a natural Movement rate of 30 feet and a natural Armor Class of 11. Some goblins ride dire wolves into combat, and large groups of goblins will often employ them to track and attack their foes.

In addition, a lair has a chance equal to 1 on 1d6 of a shaman being present (or 1-2 on 1d6 if a goblin king is present). A shaman is equivalent to a regular goblin statistically but has Clerical abilities at level 1d4+1.
monsters.name: Goblin

monsters.description: In a lair or other settlement, one out of every fifteen will be a chieftain of 5-5 Hit Dice (360 XP) in chainmail with an Armor Class of 15 (11) and movement of 10 feet that gains a +1 bonus to damage due to strength.
monsters.name: Goblin Chieftain

monsters.description:
In lairs or settlements of 30 or more goblins, there will be a goblin king of 7-7 Hit Dice (670 XP), with an Armor Class of 16 (11), wearing chainmail and carrying a shield, with a movement of 10 feet, and having a +1 bonus to damage. 

Goblins have a +2 bonus to morale while their king is present (this is not cumulative with the bonus given by a warrior leader).
monsters.name: Goblin King

monsters.description: One out of every eight goblins will be a warrior of 3-3 Hit Dice (145 XP). Goblins gain a +1 bonus to their morale if they are led by a warrior.
monsters.name: Goblin Warrior

monsters.description:
Hobgoblins are, essentially, man-sized goblins. They are better organized than their smaller kin and are also better adapted to life in the sun. Their skin tone ranges from a greenish tan to a grayish brown, and their hair and eyes are usually dark. Most wear toughened hides and carry wooden shields for armor. Like most goblinoids, they have Darkvision with a range of 30 feet.

Tribes of hobgoblins prefer to live in walled villages, or preferably in castles, and are quite willing to overrun villages or castles built by other races rather than build their own. Some tribes do choose to live underground. Hobgoblins are well-known for their animosity towards elves and will attack them whenever they think they can win.

One out of every six hobgoblins will be a warrior of 3 Hit Dice (145 XP). Regular hobgoblins gain a +1 bonus to their morale if they are led by a warrior. In hobgoblin lairs, one out of every twelve will be a chieftain of 5 Hit Dice (360 XP) wearing chainmail with an Armor Class of 15 (11) and a movement of 20 feet, having a +1 bonus to damage due to strength. In lairs of 30 or more, there will be a hobgoblin king of 7 Hit Dice (670 XP), with a shield for an Armor Class of 16 (11), and having a +2 bonus to damage. In the lair, hobgoblins never fail a morale check as long as the king is alive.

In addition, a lair has a chance equal to 1-2 on 1d6 of a shaman being present (or 1-3 on 1d6 if a hobgoblin king is present), and 1 on 1d6 of a witch or warlock. A shaman is equivalent to a hobgoblin warrior statistically, but has Clerical abilities at level 1d6+1. A witch or warlock is equivalent to a regular hobgoblin but has Magic-User abilities of level 1d6.
monsters.name: Hobgoblin

monsters.description:
Orcs are short humanoids, standing around 5 feet tall, with solidly built bodies. Their upturned noses, wide pointed ears, and beady eyes give their faces a piglike appearance. An adult orc typically weighs about 200 pounds, and this weight does not differ much between males and females. Orcs utilize all manner of weapons and armor scavenged from battlefields.

Orcs have Darkvision with a range of 60 feet. They suffer an attack penalty of -1 in bright sunlight or within the radius of a spell causing magical light. They speak their own rough and simple language, but many also speak some Common or Goblin.

One out of every eight orcs will be a warrior of 2 Hit Dice (75 XP). Orcs gain a +1 bonus to their morale if they are led by a warrior. In orc lairs, one out of every twelve will be a chieftain of 4 Hit Dice (240 XP) wearing chainmail with an Armor Class of 15 (11), a movement of 20 feet, and having a +1 bonus to damage due to strength. In lairs of 30 or more, there will be an orc king of 6 Hit Dice (500 XP), with an Armor Class of 16 (11), wearing chainmail with a shield, movement 20 feet, and having a +2 bonus to damage. In the lair, orcs never fail a morale check as long as the orc king is alive.

In addition, a lair has a chance equal to 1-2 on 1d6 of a shaman being present. A shaman is equivalent to a warrior orc statistically but has Clerical abilities at level 1d4+1.
monsters.name: Orc
Ogre
monsters.damage: 2d6 with ogre weapon (+3 with normal weapon)

monsters.name: Ogre Bully
monsters.damage: 2d6 with ogre weapon (+4 with normal weapon)

monsters.name: Ogre Pack Leader
monsters.damage: 2d6 with ogre weapon (+3 with normal weapon)

monsters.name: Giant Ant
monsters.description:
Giant ants are fantastically enlarged versions of the more common variety of ants. Normal workers are 5 to 6 feet long; queens are larger, growing up to 9 feet in length. Giant ants may be red or black; there is no statistical difference between them. Though relatively shy when first encountered, once combat begins they will fight to the death. They are known to collect shiny things, and so will sometimes have a small amount of treasure in their lair.

Giant ants may occasionally mine shiny metals such as gold or silver; one in three (1-2 on 1d6) giant ant lairs will contain 1d100 x 1d100 gp value in relatively pure nuggets.

Large and huge ants are similar to giant ants in all ways except for size; large ants are 1 to 2 feet long, while huge ants are 3 to 4 feet in length. Though smaller, their colonies have more members, and so their lair treasures are of similar size to those found in the lairs of giant ants.

monsters.name: Huge Ant
monsters.description:
Giant ants are fantastically enlarged versions of the more common variety of ants. Normal workers are 5 to 6 feet long; queens are larger, growing up to 9 feet in length. Giant ants may be red or black; there is no statistical difference between them. Though relatively shy when first encountered, once combat begins they will fight to the death. They are known to collect shiny things, and so will sometimes have a small amount of treasure in their lair.

Giant ants may occasionally mine shiny metals such as gold or silver; one in three (1-2 on 1d6) giant ant lairs will contain 1d100 x 1d100 gp value in relatively pure nuggets.

Large and huge ants are similar to giant ants in all ways except for size; large ants are 1 to 2 feet long, while huge ants are 3 to 4 feet in length. Though smaller, their colonies have more members, and so their lair treasures are of similar size to those found in the lairs of giant ants.

monsters.name: Large Ant
monsters.description:
Giant ants are fantastically enlarged versions of the more common variety of ants. Normal workers are 5 to 6 feet long; queens are larger, growing up to 9 feet in length. Giant ants may be red or black; there is no statistical difference between them. Though relatively shy when first encountered, once combat begins they will fight to the death. They are known to collect shiny things, and so will sometimes have a small amount of treasure in their lair.

Giant ants may occasionally mine shiny metals such as gold or silver; one in three (1-2 on 1d6) giant ant lairs will contain 1d100 x 1d100 gp value in relatively pure nuggets.

Large and huge ants are similar to giant ants in all ways except for size; large ants are 1 to 2 feet long, while huge ants are 3 to 4 feet in length. Though smaller, their colonies have more members, and so their lair treasures are of similar size to those found in the lairs of giant ants.

monsters.name: Giant Bombardier Beetle
monsters.description:
Giant bombardier beetles have red head and thorax sections and black abdomens. They are 3 to 4 feet long. 

In combat, a giant bombardier beetle bites opponents in front of it, and sprays a cone of very hot and noxious gases from a nozzle in the rearmost tip of the abdomen. 

This toxic blast causes 2d6 points of damage to all within a cone 10' long and 10' wide at the far end (a save vs. Death Ray for half damage is allowed).

A giant bombardier beetle can use this spray attack up to five times per day, but no more than once per three rounds. Faced with enemies attacking from one direction, a giant bombardier beetle may choose to turn away and use the spray attack rather than biting.

Giant bombardier beetles, like most beetles, have about the same visual acuity in all directions, and thus suffer no penalty to Armor Class when attacked from behind.

monsters.name: Giant Fire Beetle
monsters.description:
Giant fire beetles are huge, measuring between 18 to 30 inches in length, and possess shiny black carapaces. Each beetle has a pair of glowing red organs located just below their eyes, which emit light in a radius of 10 feet around the creature. These glands continue to emit light for 1d6 days after the beetle is killed, and may be removed and used for illumination by any adventurers not too squeamish to do so.

Despite their imposing appearance, giant fire beetles are normally timid creatures, preferring to avoid conflict. However, they will not hesitate to fight if cornered or threatened. Like most beetles, they possess roughly equal visual acuity in all directions, meaning attackers who approach from behind receive no advantage in doing so.

monsters.name: Giant Oil Beetle
monsters.description:
Giant oil beetles measure about 3 feet in length and are often found burrowing in soil or roaming dungeon corridors.

Their eyes are arranged on the sides of their heads in such a way that they can see perfectly well behind them as well as in front, negating any normal bonus for attacking from behind.

In addition to their bite, a giant oil beetle can attack with a spray of oil from its abdomen. This spray can only be applied to opponents within 5 feet behind the beetle, and an attack roll is needed to hit. Living creatures hit by this spray suffer a penalty of -2 on all attack rolls for 24 hours due to painful blisters inflicted by the irritating oil. A cure light wounds spell may be used to remove this effect, but if so used, the spell does not also restore hit points to the victim.

monsters.name: Giant Tiger Beetle
monsters.description:
Giant tiger beetles are predatory monsters around 5 feet long. Their carapaces tend to be dark brown with lighter brown striped or spotted patterns, but there are many variations.

They are fast runners, depending on their speed to run down prey, and they willingly prey on any creature of man size or smaller. Like most beetles, they have more or less the same visual acuity in all directions, and thus suffer no penalty to Armor Class when attacked from behind.

monsters.name: Giant Bee
monsters.description:
Giant bees live in hives, generally in underground areas. In each such hive will be a queen who has 2 hit dice and inflicts only a bite doing 1d8 points of damage. She is immobile, and if she is threatened all bees in the hive will fight without checking morale. The queen is worth 75 XP if defeated.

Those stung by a giant bee must save vs. Poison or die. A giant bee that successfully stings another creature pulls away, leaving its stinger in the creature; the bee then dies.

Each giant bee hive will contain honeycomb filled with honey, which is entirely safe to eat and is worth 10 GP per gallon if carefully removed. Generally 2d10+10 gallons of honey will be present in any given hive. There is also a 15% chance that one of the cells in the honeycomb will contain special honey which acts as 1d6+1 Potions of Healing if consumed. This honey can be discovered by chance, or through the use of detect magic.

monsters.name: Basilisk
monsters.description:
A basilisk is a giant six-legged lizard-like monster that petrifies living creatures with its gaze. It has dark brown, green, or black skin on its back and a pale yellow or white belly. Adults reach a body length of 5 to 7 feet with a tail of roughly equal length, and a weight of 250 to 400 pounds. There is no particular difference in size between males and females.

Any living creature meeting the gaze of a basilisk must save vs. Petrify or be turned to stone instantly. In general, any creature surprised by the basilisk will meet its gaze. Those who attempt to fight the monster while averting their eyes suffer penalties of -4 to attack and -2 to AC. It is possible to use a mirror to fight the monster, in which case the penalties are -2 to attack and no penalty to AC. If a basilisk sees its own reflection in a mirror, it must save vs. Petrify or be turned to stone; a petrified basilisk loses its power to petrify. Basilisks instinctively avoid mirrors or other reflective surfaces, even drinking with their eyes closed. However, if an attacker can manage to surprise the monster with a mirror, it may see its reflection.

The greater basilisk appears identical to the common variety, save that it is larger, having a body length of about 8 feet with a 7 to 9-foot-long tail and weighing between 400 and 750 pounds. The skin of the greater basilisk is toxic to the touch, such that any living creature bitten by one or who touches one with bare skin must save vs. Poison or die. This effect persists even after the monster is dead, typically for about 2d20 hours. The only way to tell if the effect has subsided is to touch the corpse, an obviously bad idea.
